title: 109_s608
content: The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section establishing the Office of Pension Participant Advocacy. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to establish the Office of Pension Participant Advocacy within the Department of Labor. The office will be led by the Pension Participant Advocate, who must have experience in pension participant assistance and be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with advocacy organizations. The Advocate will report directly to the Secretary and receive compensation at the Senior Executive Service rate. The Office of Pension Participant Advocacy, established under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, evaluates efforts to assist and protect pension plan participants. It serves as a focal point for information on policies affecting participants and identifies problems and capabilities to address them. The Office of Pension Participant Advocacy, established under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, evaluates efforts to assist and protect pension plan participants by promoting the expansion of pension plan coverage, increasing awareness of pension plans, protecting participants' rights, and forming partnerships to help participants receive their benefits. The Pension Participant Advocate aims to advocate for pension plan participants' rights, prioritize low and moderate-income participants, and provide necessary information on pension plans. They are required to submit an annual report to specific committees in the House of Representatives. The Pension Participant Advocate submits an annual report to Congress, identifying significant problems, proposing legislative changes, and reporting on actions taken to address previous issues. Additionally, specific reports are submitted to the Secretary or other appropriate officials. The Pension Participant Advocate must report identified problems to the Secretary or appropriate official. Reports must be submitted directly to Congress without prior review. The Advocate has the power to request necessary information and appear as needed. The Pension Participant Advocate can represent pension plan participants before Federal agencies and contract for statistical information and surveys. The Office of Pension Participant Advocacy, established under Subtitle D, will be effective starting January 1, 2006.
